title: Classic Hi-Fi Equipment
description: For the audiophiles who remember tube amplifiers, reel-to-reel, and the quest for perfect sound

questions.question: What type of amplifier, using glass tubes that glowed orange, was prized by audiophiles for its warm sound quality?
What tape format used open spools of magnetic tape and was considered the highest quality home recording method in the 1950s and 1960s?
Which legendary American hi-fi company, founded in 1927, was known for its Klipschorn speakers?
What audio component, positioned between the turntable and the amplifier, boosted the very weak signal from a phono cartridge?
What McIntosh hi-fi component was famous for its distinctive blue-lit glass front panel?
What Danish audio company became famous for its sleek, modern designs and high-end turntables and speakers?
What did audiophiles call the practice of connecting separate components (receiver, turntable, speakers) rather than buying an all-in-one unit?
What Dolby technology, introduced for consumer cassette decks in the 1970s, reduced tape hiss?
Which Japanese brand was known for its silver-faced receivers that became iconic hi-fi components in the 1970s?
What type of speaker, requiring no external amplification and using electrostatic panels, was made by companies like Quad and Martin Logan?
What was the term for the heavy, rotating metal plate on a turntable that the vinyl record sits on?
What type of turntable drive system, considered superior by many audiophiles, used a rubber belt to spin the platter?
Which iconic Maxell cassette tape advertisement showed a man being blown back in his chair by powerful speakers?
What feature on a graphic equalizer allowed listeners to adjust the bass, midrange, and treble frequencies individually?
What brand introduced the Walkman portable cassette player in 1979, revolutionizing personal audio?
